subjectData.thoughts: I am curious to know what the purpose of this experiment is. Some feedback is to give clearer instructions as to what everything means. Such as the average means what? In terms of units or whatever it may be.
subjectData.strategies: If the questions had to do with budget for things that did not affect anyone's health or safety, such as the budget for hiring question, I made the budget disproportional. However, for the questions with bail and meals, people would be directly affected and each region deserves to have these resources. Thus I made these budgets/resources equal.
subjectData.userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.149 Safari/537.36

trials.prompt: A corporate recruiter is seeking to fill a position at their company. They have limited recruiting budget, and each group uses different job search services, each with different success rates at delivering qualified applicants. The values below show the number of applicants in each group for a fixed advertising budget. How should they allocate their advertising dollars?

Meals on Wheels is tasked with delivering meals to homebound persons. Their time and reseources are limited, and some groups live further away, so delivering to some groups may mean less deliveries to others. The numbers below represent how many meals are given to each group. How should they allocate their time for deliveries?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators. How should the hospital allocate their respirators?

Meals on Wheels is tasked with delivering meals to homebound persons. Their time and reseources are limited, and some groups live further away, so delivering to some groups may mean less deliveries to others. The numbers below represent how many meals are given to each group. How should they allocate their time for deliveries?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators. How should the hospital allocate their respirators?

A bank must decide who to give home loans to. Only 10% of the loans can default and some groups are more likely to default than others, so giving loans to some people may result in less loans for others. How should the loans be allocated?

A local newspaper company is trying to decide how to divide up the paper routes. Some groups of delivery people are faster than others, and if too many papers don't get delivered, customers get angry. Giving more to one delivery group may mean less for others. The icons below show how many routes are given to each group. How should they divide up the routes?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators. This is a test trial to help calibrate your responses. Please move your slider all the way to the left. Thank you.

A local courthouse is deciding who to give bail to. Their goal is to maintain a constant level of public safety. Some groups are more likely to commit crimes than others. Giving bail to some people may mean not giving bail to others. The icons below show the percentage of each group receiving bail. How should they allocate bail?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators.
